visibility_factors: Potential very low visibility reported in the overnight hours (likely patchy fog/ice-crystal haze or reporting artifact)
Late-night snow shower around 11 PM may reduce visibility to ~3 miles
Any freezing drizzle/freezing rain can create localized slick spots even without big snow totals

alert_summary.description: Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to an ice jam; advisory in effect until 7:00 PM EST Thursday (2026-01-29).

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI on Friday 2026-01-30, this looks like a VERY cold day (near/under 0°F overnight, only low teens by midday) with light/trace precipitation. Snow amounts are negligible (~0.04"), so this is not a classic Michigan snow-accumulation closure setup. The bigger concern is ice: the daily forecast calls for light freezing rain, and with temperatures solidly below freezing all day, any freezing drizzle/freezing rain would stick immediately and create slick roads/sidewalks—especially bridges, overpasses, and untreated neighborhood streets. Winds are light (max ~9 mph), so blowing snow is not an issue. Visibility is mostly okay once daytime starts, but the overnight hours show extremely low reported visibility (0 miles) which could indicate patchy fog/ice crystals or a data artifact; if it’s real, it could briefly worsen the early-morning commute. Overall: LOW snow-day probability from snow, but a MODERATE risk of delays/closures if freezing rain actually occurs near the pre-dawn to morning commute window (roughly 5–9 AM) and surfaces become glazed before treatment.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Trace-to-very-light freezing drizzle/freezing rain overnight with very cold temps (around 0°F to single digits) and light winds, followed by a dry/mostly sunny daytime. Main risk is thin glaze on untreated neighborhood roads, sidewalks, and bus-stop areas rather than plowable snow.

Cold, quiet high-pressure day (teens for highs, sub-zero lows) with minimal snowfall and no wind-driven blowing/drifting. Roads generally improve quickly after daybreak if crews pre-treat main routes.

Late-night light snow burst (near/after 10–11 PM) after an otherwise calm day—can create slick travel for evening activities, but it typically does not impact next-morning school operations unless it continues into the commute window.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Late January in West Michigan commonly supports sustained subfreezing temperatures and periodic light snow. School closures in this part of Michigan are more often driven by (1) significant snow during the morning commute (often ~8–10+ inches with poor timing), (2) widespread ice storms/freezing rain with meaningful glazing, or (3) extreme wind chills (often around -15°F or colder).
unusual_factors: Forecast calls for "Light freezing rain" with very low precipitation totals (0.01 in liquid; ~trace snow). Even a trace glaze can be higher-impact than the snow totals suggest, but coverage and timing matter.

Very cold morning: forecast low near -8°F and morning wind chills roughly -10°F to about -18°F. This is cold but generally not in the typical all-district closure range unless wind chills trend closer to or below ~-15°F for an extended period and/or coincide with other hazards.
Winds are light (max ~9 mph), which limits blowing/drifting and reduces the chance of a true blizzard-style closure.

local_microclimates: Rockford sits in the Grand Rapids metro’s northern tier; temps can run a bit colder than the urban core, which increases the chance that any moisture becomes glaze (especially on bridges/overpasses).
River/low-lying areas and shaded back roads can hold slick spots longer in subfreezing temps, even when main roads improve.
infrastructure_considerations: West Michigan districts and road commissions are generally equipped for routine snow; minimal snow amounts alone rarely close school.
Ice is the bigger operational issue: untreated subdivision roads, rural connectors, parking lots, and bus turnarounds can remain slick if even a thin glaze forms before crews pre-treat.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Minor rolling terrain can create isolated slick hills; not a major elevation-driven snowbelt effect here compared with true lake-effect zones closer to Lake Michigan.

history.confidence_assessment: For Friday 2026-01-30 in Rockford, the forecast shows very cold temperatures with minimal snow accumulation and only trace liquid, but a 'light freezing rain' signal overnight. Historically, this setup produces a LOW-to-LOW-MODERATE snow-day risk overall, with the key swing factor being whether a thin glaze develops on untreated roads before the early commute (especially 5–8 AM). If freezing drizzle is patchy or ends early, districts typically stay open (maybe with caution). If glazing is widespread and coincides with the bus/parent drop-off window, closure/delay odds rise despite the tiny precip totals.

safety_recommendations: School-day cancellation is unlikely based on the Friday (2026-01-30) forecast: precipitation is very light (trace) and winds are modest; the main hazard is spotty refreeze/black ice from any light freezing drizzle overnight plus very cold pavement temps.
Prioritize early-morning treatment (salt/brine where effective) on bridges, overpasses, ramps, hills, shaded stretches, and known slick intersections—especially 5:30–8:00 AM.
Have buses run conservative speeds and extend following distance; anticipate intermittent slick spots rather than widespread snow-covered roads.
Increase attention to loading zones, sidewalks, and parking lots: even thin glaze can create slip-and-fall risk; apply grit/sand where salt performance is limited in extreme cold.
Communicate to families/staff: allow extra time, watch for black ice, and dress for extreme cold (wind chills roughly -10°F to -20°F around the morning commute).
Monitor late-evening Friday (around 11 PM) for a burst of snow; while it should not affect Friday school operations, it may impact evening events and set up slick spots for Saturday morning.

news.key_findings_summary: For Friday, January 30, 2026 in the Rockford, Michigan area, the strongest signals are weather-driven and center on dangerous cold/wind chills overnight Thursday into Friday morning, which can prompt delays/closures even without heavy new snowfall. Rockford Public Schools’ most recent district-level messaging (posted January 27, 2026) discusses ongoing winter impacts and their early-morning road-check decision process but does not (in the material captured) announce a Friday 1/30 closure/delay. Neighboring-district context shows recent closures in the region (Forest Hills closed Tue 1/27; Sparta closed Fri 1/23), which can be a weak ‘domino’ indicator if Friday morning wind chills are severe enough. parking_lots.estimated_clear_time: School lots typically cleared early morning; risk of glazed surfaces if any freezing drizzle occurred overnight and refroze.

clearing_timeline.snow_end_time: Light freezing drizzle/freezing rain signal mainly earlier (Thu evening into Fri pre-dawn); by 06:00–09:00 forecast trends drier/clear. Any residual moisture likely refreezes given subzero/teens temperatures.

If earlier freezing precip leaves even a thin glaze, subzero wind chills and very cold pavement can keep roads slick into the bus window (~06:30). Major routes should be treated first and are likely passable; the decision risk concentrates on shaded rural roads, neighborhood streets, bridges/overpasses, and untreated parking areas.

final.decision_rationale:
Checklist synthesis and weighting (Meteorology 25%, Safety 25%, History 15%, News 15%, Infrastructure 10%, Power 5%, Web verify 5%):
1) Agreement: All experts agree snow accumulation is negligible and the only meaningful hazards are (a) extreme cold exposure and (b) patchy ice/black ice from trace freezing precip/refreeze. Power outage risk is not currently a driver.
2) Disagreement: The key conflict is wind chill severity during the bus window. WeatherAPI suggests bus-window wind chills mostly above the automatic threshold (>-20°F), while Weather.com shows multiple hours ≤ -20°F (roughly -25°F). Web verifier flags this as a major discrepancy and cannot confirm ≤ -20°F across TWO independent hourly sources.
3) Plow timing math: Precip/icing risk is mainly Thu evening to ~midnight, giving ~6+ hours to 06:30 for treatment. Infrastructure expects main routes mostly drivable by 06:30, but secondary/local bus-route segments remain variable due to extreme cold reducing salt effectiveness. This supports ‘delay more likely than closure’ framing.
4) Ice: Yes—patchy glaze/black ice is plausible; that elevates risk even with no snow.
5) Neighboring districts: No confirmed Fri 1/30 closures/delays located in checks; therefore no +15–20% boost.
6) Power: Systemwide outages very low (17 customers affected reported); no evidence of widespread heating/power failure risk.
7) Wind chill verification: Threshold risk is plausible (Weather.com ≤ -20°F), but not corroborated by a second hourly source; hence not a near-automatic closure call.
8) What would make this wrong: If NWS/Kent County messaging and multiple sources verify sustained ≤ -20°F wind chills at 06:00–08:00, closure odds jump sharply. Conversely, if wind chills are closer to -10°F to -15°F and icing is minimal, odds drop and school likely opens (possibly with a delay).

Final calibration: Baseline for ‘no snow, but patchy ice + very cold’ is low-to-low-moderate. I’m setting 30% for a full closure because (i) a credible source indicates wind chills below the -20°F threshold at bus time and (ii) black ice risk on secondary roads is non-trivial in extreme cold. Lack of confirmed neighboring closures, low outage risk, and likely-passable main roads keep it from rising above ~35–40%.

alternative_scenarios.impact: Closure becomes more likely (could rise to ~60–80% if sustained and district is strict on wind-chill policy).

positions.rationale: For Rockford, MI on Fri 2026-01-30, the meteorological ingredients for a classic snow day (heavy snow, strong winds, low vis) are not present. The credible closure lever is **cold exposure at bus stops**: with forecast lows near -8°F and wind chills potentially below -20°F for several pre-dawn hours (per the web verifier/Weather.com), districts sometimes close or delay even under dry skies. However, the coldest period is largely **before/around sunrise**, and winds are not strong; many districts may opt for a **delay** rather than a full cancellation unless their policy has a hard wind-chill threshold. With only trace freezing precip indicated, I’d keep the full snow-day probability in the low-to-low-moderate range, but above baseline because of the plausible sub -20°F wind chills overlapping early bus windows.
keyFactors: Minimal snow/precip amounts for Fri 2026-01-30 (trace liquid ~0.01 in; snow ~0.04 in) → not an accumulation-driven closure setup.

Main meteorological hazard is **extreme cold**: temps near/below 0°F overnight (low ~-8°F) with morning wind chills likely in the **-15°F to -25°F** range. WeatherAPI bottoms near ~-19°F, but the verifier notes Weather.com showing **multiple hours < -20°F (roughly 2–8 AM)**, which can trigger cold-based closure/delay policies.

Icing risk exists but looks **light/trace**: “light freezing rain” signal with very small QPF and light winds. That supports **spotty glaze/black ice**, mainly on untreated surfaces (bridges/ramps/neighborhood streets), more consistent with a **delay** than a full closure unless coverage is widespread right at bus time.

Winds are light (~5–9 mph) → no blowing snow/drifting; visibility concerns appear inconsistent (0 mi readings overnight look like an artifact or shallow fog/ice-crystal haze rather than a sustained whiteout).

positions.rationale:
I’m placing the snow-day (full closure) probability at **18%** for Rockford, MI on **Friday, Jan 30, 2026**. Historically, this type of day (trace freezing drizzle/freezing rain, very cold, light winds, minimal snow) produces more *operational friction* than plowable conditions: isolated black ice on neighborhood streets, hills, and bridges can prompt cautious routing and sometimes a 2-hour delay, but full cancellations are less common unless either (1) glazing is more widespread than forecast totals imply, or (2) wind chills are clearly below a district’s threshold for multiple hours around bus-stop time.

Given the peer verification that at least one major public forecast has wind chills **below -20°F for several early-morning hours**, I’m nudging the closure probability up from what I’d typically assign for “trace ice + calm” (often closer to ~10–15%) to **18%**. Still, the combination of light winds, minimal new snow, and improving daytime conditions keeps this from being a high-probability closure day.
keyFactors: Historical closure patterns in West Michigan: districts rarely close for *light/trace snow* alone; closure usually needs either (a) significant snow timed into the commute, (b) meaningful glazing/freezing rain, or (c) extreme wind chills at/near operational thresholds.

This forecast is a classic “looks quiet but can bite” setup: trace precip (0.01" liquid) + ‘light freezing rain’ label + temps well below freezing = black-ice risk, but historically that more often yields *delays* than full-day cancellations unless it’s widespread at bus-route time.

The biggest history-driven swing factor is *extreme cold policy*: WeatherAPI suggests wind chills mostly around ~-10°F to ~-19°F (borderline), but the WebWeatherVerifier indicates another major source (Weather.com) shows several hours below -20°F in the pre-dawn/morning window. Historically, when multiple hours fall below local “danger threshold,” closures/delays rise even without snow.

Timing matters: the worst precip signal in the hourly data appears around midnight (00:00) with drying/clearing by the morning commute; late-night snow (~23:00) is after the school decision window and is tiny. That timing historically suppresses full cancellations.

Regional recent-closure context (nearby districts closing earlier in the week) is a *weak* domino factor: it can slightly increase the chance administrators lean conservative, but it doesn’t override a low-precip, low-wind day unless cold/wind chill crosses policy triggers.
Derived from primary analysis

positions.rationale: As the NEWS specialist, I weight (a) whether there’s a strong public-facing trigger (NWS cold advisory/wind-chill messaging) and (b) whether districts are already signaling operational disruption. The meteorology peers show minimal snow and light winds, which normally means school stays open. The swing factor is wind chill: if Rockford-area wind chills spend multiple hours below ~-20°F before buses run, many districts consider delays/closures for student exposure at bus stops. Because the WeatherAPI feed is near that threshold but Weather.com (per verifier) is clearly below it, I move the probability up from “low” to “low-moderate.” Still, absent confirmed local road/power disruption or an explicit district statement, I don’t go above ~30%.
keyFactors: Primary hazard is *extreme cold/wind chill* rather than snow: forecast lows near -8°F with wind chills plausibly below -20°F for several pre-dawn hours (per WebWeatherVerifier’s Weather.com comparison).

Precip totals are *tiny* (≈0.01" liquid; ≈0.04" snow), so a classic snow-accumulation closure is unlikely; however the stated condition is “light freezing rain,” which can produce a thin glaze that matters disproportionately.

Timing: any freezing drizzle/ice risk appears strongest overnight (around midnight–2 AM in the safety read), with the school commute risk hinging on whether that leaves untreated slick spots and whether crews can effectively treat in very cold pavement temps.

News/district signals are mixed: local coverage emphasizes cold advisories/wind chills into Friday morning; Rockford Public Schools had no posted closure/delay signal as of the last check, which tilts toward “open” absent deterioration overnight.

Domino context exists (recent nearby closures), but there’s no strong community intel (road impassability, widespread event cancellations, or power outages) pointing to an imminent district-wide shutdown.

debates.topic: The historical rates presented look plausible, but they may not capture districts’ *policy-driven cold thresholds* (wind chill-based) that can override the usual “no snow = no closure” pattern.
debates.challenge: The historical rates presented look plausible, but they may not capture districts’ *policy-driven cold thresholds* (wind chill-based) that can override the usual “no snow = no closure” pattern.

positions.rationale: I’m setting **25%** for a full snow day (closure) for **Fri 2026-01-30** in Rockford, MI—slightly higher than my prior 22% due to the cross-source signal that wind chills may be materially colder than the WeatherAPI hourly feed. Meteorologically, there’s no accumulating-snow or wind/visibility setup that typically forces closures. The only plausible closure lever is *student safety in extreme cold* (especially if wind chills are clearly ≤ -20°F during the morning commute) plus any patchy black ice from trace freezing precip. Absent a stronger/longer-duration precip event or higher winds, I can’t justify going as high as 40% for a full cancellation; I’d expect “open or delay” to be the modal outcome.
keyFactors: Snow/visibility-driven closure is unlikely: forecast snow is essentially a trace (~0.09 cm / ~0.04") with light winds (<10 mph), so no blowing/drifting or sustained low-visibility commute impact is evident.

Primary weather risk is *extreme cold exposure* at bus-stop time: WeatherAPI has wind chills near ~-19°F (just shy of common -20°F triggers), while the verifier cites Weather.com showing several hours *below* -20°F (roughly 2–8 AM). If that verifies locally in Rockford, it can push districts toward a delay/closure even with dry roads.

Secondary risk is *thin glaze/black ice* from very light freezing drizzle/freezing rain: even tiny QPF can matter when pavement temps are far below freezing and salt efficacy is reduced. This is more consistent with a 2-hour delay than a full closure unless glazing is widespread and untreated.

Timing favors operations: the coldest period is pre-dawn; daytime looks quiet/sunny. Unless the sub -20°F wind chills overlap the actual bus window (roughly ~6–8 AM) and policy is strict, districts often choose delay over cancellation.

positions.rationale: I’m at **24%** for a full snow day (closure) on **Friday, Jan 30, 2026**—up from my prior 18% because the *verified* possibility of sub-(-20°F) wind chills overlapping the bus-stop window is a historically meaningful closure trigger in Michigan even when snowfall is near-zero. Still, the precip totals are tiny, winds are light (limiting blowing/drifting), and daytime conditions look benign; that combination historically produces more 2-hour delays than outright cancellations, keeping the closure probability below ~30%.
keyFactors: Historically, Rockford-area closures are much more sensitive to (a) widespread ice/glaze and (b) extreme wind chills at bus-stop time than to “cold but dry” days; here snow totals are negligible, so the decision is about *exposure + slick spots*, not plowing.

Forecast signal includes **light freezing rain** with tiny QPF (0.01" liquid). Historically these “trace glaze” setups most often yield *delays* rather than full closures—*unless* glaze is more widespread than the totals imply or it coincides exactly with the early commute (roughly 5:30–8:00 AM).

The web-verifier discrepancy matters: Weather.com showing **multiple hours below -20°F wind chill** (roughly pre-dawn through near sunrise) increases the historical odds of a closure/delay vs. WeatherAPI’s ~-19°F floor. If Rockford Public Schools has a hard threshold around -20°F, that materially elevates closure probability even with minimal precip.

Recent regional precedent (neighboring districts closed on Tue 1/27 and Fri 1/23) slightly increases the likelihood of conservative decision-making (“domino context”), but it’s a weak signal without a current announcement.

Operationally, extreme cold reduces salt effectiveness; even small amounts of freezing drizzle can translate into persistent slick patches on secondary/residential roads and bus turnarounds, which are historically more predictive of disruption than conditions on trunklines.

positions.rationale: As SAFETY, I’m weighting student exposure (bus-stop wind chills) and low-probability/high-consequence roadway hazards (thin glaze/black ice) over raw snowfall totals. Given the verifier’s credible possibility of sub -20°F wind chills for multiple hours near the early-morning window—and the fact that even trace freezing drizzle can create localized but serious slick spots when temps are near/under 0°F—I see a meaningful chance the district opts for a delay or closure. However, because winds are light, snow totals are negligible, and daytime travel improves markedly, a *full snow day* is still not the most likely outcome. Net: I’m lowering my prior 40% to 30%, aligning more with the meteorology/news direction while still above history’s baseline due to the wind-chill threshold risk.
keyFactors: Wind chill risk may cross a practical/automatic decision threshold: WeatherAPI bottoms near ~-19°F wind chill, but the web verifier flags Weather.com showing ~-22°F to ~-27°F for several hours (roughly 2–8 AM), which overlaps bus-stop/first-bus windows.
Very cold pavement + any trace freezing drizzle/freezing rain increases black-ice probability on bridges/ramps/neighborhood streets even when total precip is tiny (0.01" liquid; trace snow).
Most of the day looks dry/clear with light winds and negligible snow accumulation, which argues against a *full* closure and more toward “operate with caution” or a delay.
Salt effectiveness is reduced in extreme cold; even small untreated areas (school lots, sidewalks, bus loops) can stay slick, increasing slip-and-fall risk and bus loading hazards.
No strong signals of widespread power disruption or a major ice storm; the NWS alert shown is a flood advisory in Newaygo County (not a direct Rockford/Kent County closure trigger).

positions.rationale: I’m landing at **30%** for a full snow day (closure) for **Friday, January 30, 2026** in Rockford, MI. From a news/operations lens, closures tend to correlate with either (1) widespread travel disruption (heavy snow/ice), (2) power/heat failures, or (3) an unusually strong, repeated public safety trigger (e.g., wind chills well below -20°F during bus times). Here, (1) is not present (trace precip), (2) is not evidenced locally, and (3) is plausible but not fully locked due to forecast spread. That combination supports “low-to-low-moderate” odds for a closure, with a meaningful chance of a **delay** instead.
keyFactors: Public-facing hazard signal is **extreme cold/wind chill** (local media framing + NWS Grand Rapids context) rather than plowable snow.
Forecast snow totals are **negligible** (~0.09 cm / ~0.04 in) and winds are light (<10 mph), which usually keeps districts open (often at most a delay).

**Forecast disagreement on wind chills**: WeatherAPI bottoms near ~-19°F feels-like, but the verifier notes Weather.com showing multiple hours **below -20°F** (roughly -22°F to -27°F) during the pre-dawn/bus-stop window—this is the one factor that can flip decisions.
No strong “domino” signal yet: no Rockford-specific closure/delay posted for Fri 1/30; nearby recent closures (Forest Hills Tue 1/27, Sparta Fri 1/23) are only weakly predictive.
No current outage/major disruption narrative: systemwide outages look low and there’s no Rockford-specific road-impassability bulletin surfaced.

If your model is effectively combining ‘delay or closure’ probabilities, it may be overcounting—meteorology here supports delays more than cancellations unless you assume widespread glazing or a strict wind-chill closure policy at/below -20°F during bus time.
debates.challenge: 40% feels high for a *full closure* given (1) negligible snow totals, (2) light winds, and (3) improving daytime conditions. If your model is effectively combining ‘delay or closure’ probabilities, it may be overcounting—meteorology here supports delays more than cancellations unless you assume widespread glazing or a strict wind-chill closure policy at/below -20°F during bus time.

collaboration.collaborationSummary: Agents reached consensus after 2 round(s) with 6.0% spread. Average probability: 27%.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 28 at 4:22PM EST until January 29 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.

* WHERE...A portion of west central Michigan, including the
following county, Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Thursday.

* IMPACTS...Ice jams are notoriously unpredictable. Low-lying areas
along the Muskegon River that are prone to flooding may see
rapidly changing water levels as ice shifts and adjusts.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 418 PM EST, an ice jam continues to be reported by local
authorities on the Muskegon river in southern Newaygo County.
The river gauge at Newaygo shows water levels remaining at
minor flood stage as of Wednesday afternoon.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. While
flooding associated with freeze up ice jams is typically
minor, conditions can change rapidly and unpredictably.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Newaygo.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement and request they pass this information to the National
Weather Service when you can do so safely.
